pages.text: Most MIDI devices can send and receive data for multiple different tracks - called Channels - to allow them to play multiple different instruments at the same time.$(br2)Most devices support up to 16 channels that can each manage their own program, notes, volume, and more independently of the other channels.

pages.title: Channel Usage
pages.text: While the MIDI standard defines 16 channels not every device or sequence will use them all.$(br2)Some controllers, like a digital piano, may only send data to a single channel. Conversely, some MIDI sequences may use all 16 at the same time to create complex music.

pages.title: Channel 10
pages.text: The MIDI standard says that channel 10 should be used only for percussion.$(br2)Percussion has a huge number of unique sounds (often one per note) rather than the same sound with a different pitch (like a piano) so it must be handled in a special way.$(br2)As a result nearly all MIDI sequences use channel 10 for percussion and nothing else.
